awd_titl_txt: Student Travel Support for the 2010 USENIX Annual Technical Conference
awd_abstract_narration:
This project funds US-based graduate students to attend the 2010 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (ATC), the premier forum for advanced professionals from academic and industrial backgrounds. ATC brings together researchers from across the networking and systems community (computer networking, security, cloud computing, and operating systems) to foster cross-disciplinary approaches and to address shared research challenges. This cross-disciplinary emphasis makes ATC well-suited for broadening student awareness and participation in the field. Participation in USENIX ATC?10 and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers, and exposes students to leading work in the field. 

This project enables about 11 US-based graduate students who may otherwise be unable to attend to participate in ATC'10.  Held June 22-25 in Boston, MA., ATC'10 consists of 4 days of mini-conferences, workshops and training, and a 3-day technical program.  Over 500 researchers and practitioners attend annually.

Students receiving assistance serve as scribes who write summaries of conference sessions for a future issue of the ;login: magazine, participate in the Student Birds-of-a-Feather session, and are strongly encouraged to present posters and works-in-progress. Students are recruited through an open, well advertised process, and selected by a committee appointed by the ATC program chair and USENIX board.

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled eleven graduate students enrolled at American universities to attend and participate in the 2010 USENIX Annual Technical Conference (http://static.usenix.org/events/atc10/) held in Boston MA, June 22-25, 2010.  The conference program included presentation of 24 technical papers selected by peer review from 155 submissions.  Presented papers covered computer science topics including information security, energy efficiency in desktop and handheld computers, cloud storage, efficient network processing, computer memory error impact, parallel computation, coordinating internet-scale systems, NAND flash memory systems, wide-area network acceleration, techniques for higher-precision testing. Colocated with the conference were workshops on storage tecnology, cloud computing, supercomputing operating systems, Internet applications, computer system configuration management and online social networks.

The eleven students were selected by competition based on their preparation in the area of research the conference serves, their willingness to participate in conference support activities, the degree to which this award provided a new opportunity to the student and their financial need. No funds were spent supporting the administration of this project by Carnegie Mellon University or USENIX Association.

The students supported were enrolled in graduate studies at the University of Tennessee (Knoxville), Binghamton University, Duke University, the University of Rochester, the University of California (San Diego), the University of California (Santa Cruz), Pennsylvania State University, Columbia University, and Iowa State University.
